Cell viability remained unaffected after exposure to Aβ alone (Supplementary Fig. S2). mtGSH is the primary line of defense for maintaining a suitable mitochondrial redox environment [60]. To restore the compromised pool of mtGSH in Cu-treated cells, we used the cell-permeable derivative GSHee. As expected, GSHee treatment (1 mM) partially recovered mtGSH levels (Fig. 1C) and counteracted the generation of ROS induced by Cu and Aβ (Fig. 1D). Similar results were obtained when cells were incubated with mitochondria-targeted antioxidants such as the superoxide scavenger Mito-TEMPO (5 μM) [61] and MitoQ (1 μM) [62]. In both cases, the increased synthesis of superoxide after Cu exposure was significantly blunted (Fig. 1E), thus confirming that Cu-induced oxidative stress originates mainly in mitochondria. Oxidative stress was also measured using the fluorogenic probe DCFH2-DA (Supplementary Fig. S3). Originally devised as a marker for H2O2 generation, it is now known that DCFH2 does not react directly with superoxide or H2O2 [63]; however, it can be indirectly oxidized by hydroxyl radicals generated from redox-active metals [64]. Consistent with this, cells incubated with Cu showed increased DCF fluorescence, which was reduced by treatment with MitoQ.Fig. 1
Sublethal doses of Cu enhance Aβ-mediated mitochondrial oxidative stress in a dose-dependent manner. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to increasing doses of Cu with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. (A) Cell viability assessed by MTT assay. Results are expressed as % relative to control (CTRL) cells. (B) Mitochondrial Cu (mtCu) levels analyzed in the mitochondrial fraction and expressed as fold-change relative to CTRL values. (C) Total mitochondrial glutathione (mtGSH) levels in control and Cu-loaded cells with and without GSH ethyl ester (GSHee) treatment. (D) Spectrofluorimetric measurements of dihydroethidium (DHE) fluorescence, indicating a Cu dose-dependent generation of reactive oxidative species (ROS), which is enhanced by exposure to Aβ (5 μM) and inhibited by GSHee (1 mM) treatment. Tert-butyl-hydroperoxide (tBHP, 500 μM) was used as a positive control. (E) Spectrofluorimetric measurements of DHE fluorescence showing a significant reduction of Cu-induced ROS after treatment with the mitochondria-targeted antioxidants MitoQ (1 μM) and MitoTEMPO (5 μM). (F–H) The mitochondrial fraction was isolated from control and Cu-loaded cells with and without MitoQ (1 μM) or Ab (5 μM) treatment. (F) Reduced levels of glutathione (GSH) and its oxidized form (GSSG). The GSH/GSSG ratio was calculated as an indicator of redox status. (G) Protein carbonyl content. (H) Aconitase activity assessed by the rate of isocitrate formation. (I) ATP levels. Data are shown as mean ± SD (n = 3–6 independent experiments performed in triplicate). Unpaired t-test (A) and one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test (B–E) were applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001).Fig. 1

To better understand the impact of high Cu levels on mitochondrial function, we subsequently evaluated various markers related to oxidative damage. The findings revealed a decline in the GSH/GSSG ratio in mitochondria from Cu-overloaded cells (Fig. 1F), along with elevated protein carbonyl content (Fig. 1G). The mitochondrial damage linked to high Cu levels was further evidenced by the loss of catalytic activity of mitochondrial aconitase (Fig. 1H), a TCA cycle enzyme containing an iron–sulfur cluster that is highly sensitive to oxidative modifications [65] and a direct target of Cu toxicity [66]. The deleterious effect of Cu on mitochondrial function was amplified by Aβ exposure, showing an enhanced inhibitory effect on aconitase activity and lower ATP levels (Fig. 1H and I). In contrast, treatment with the mitochondrial antioxidant MitoQ significantly reduced GSSG levels (Fig. 1F). The recovery of GSH redox balance by MitoQ was accompanied by decreased protein carbonyl formation and full aconitase reactivation (Fig. 1G and H), which led to partial restoration of ATP levels (Fig. 1I).

sec.title: Aβ-induced mitochondrial impairment, exacerbated by high Cu levels, activates mitochondrial quality control mechanisms that affect the mtDNA content
sec.p:
Mitochondrial damage initiates a selective autophagy-mediated clearance, known as mitophagy, which prevents the buildup of dysfunctional mitochondria [67]. To assess whether Cu-mediated oxidative stress induces mitophagy, cells were stained with the fluorophore Mtphagy alongside fluorescent probes specific for mitochondria (MitoTraker Deep Red) and lysosomes (Lyso dye) (Fig. 2A). The Mtphagy dye, which remains stable in healthy mitochondria, emits bright fluorescence when phagosomes containing mitochondria fuse with lysosomes [68]. As shown, Cu exposure (100 μM) activated mitophagy (Fig. 2A and B), which was inhibited by GSHee treatment (1 mM) or the autophagy inhibitor wortmannin (5 μM). Aβ-treated cells showed enhanced Mtphagy fluorescence, indicative of an increased mitophagy rate; however, this increase was markedly attenuated when microglia were subjected to Cu overload (Fig. 2A and B). Next, we evaluated the mtDNA copy number as a measure of the mitochondrial content (Fig. 2C). We performed a multiplex dPCR assay using two different primer pairs targeting opposing regions of mtDNA: one region with a low frequency of deletions (mmt86-ND1) and another with a high frequency of deletions (mmt71-ND4), enabling simultaneous assessment of the deletion rate. Remarkably, despite the activation of mitophagy, Cu-overloaded cells showed elevated mtDNA copy number (Fig. 2C). The rise in mtDNA content caused by high Cu levels was more pronounced in cells subjected to Aβ (5 μM) and was prevented by MitoQ administration. These findings suggest that a compensatory response is triggered to counteract mitochondrial oxidative stress caused by mtCu enrichment, enhancing mtDNA synthesis. Additionally, we calculated the mmt71-ND4/mmt86-ND1 ratio to determine the proportion of mtDNA molecules with deletions. In all the cases, the ratio approached one (Fig. 2C), signifying a lack of deletions.Fig. 2
Cu overload stimulates mitophagy and mitochondrial biogenesis. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidants GSH ethyl ester (GSHee, 1 mM) and MitoQ (1 μM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. (A and B) Mitophagy flux assay using Mtphagy dye. (A) Representative confocal images showing colocalization of Mtphagy dye (red) with lysosomes (Lyso dye, green). An increase in Mtphagy dye fluorescence intensity indicates the recruitment of mitochondria to lysosomes. Mitochondria were labelled using MitoTracker Deep Red (MTK; magenta). To inhibit autophagy, cells were incubated with wortmannin (Wn, 5 μM) for 24 h. Scale bar: 25 μm. (B) Mitophagy quantification assessed as the relative fluorescence intensity of Mtphagy dye divided by the relative fluorescence intensity of MTK. Three non-overlapping images randomly captured from the upper, middle, and lower areas were analyzed (n = 3 independent experiments). (C) Quantification of mtDNA copies by multiplex dPCR assay using two different primer pairs (mmt86-ND1 and mmt71-ND4). The right histogram shows the mtDNA deletion ratio (mmt71-ND4/mmt86-ND1) (n = 5–6 independent experiments). (D) Immunoblots displaying the relative levels of mtTFA in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). (E) Immunoblot analysis of the respiratory chain proteins SDHA (nuclear-encoded) and COX-1 (mitochondria-encoded) in cell extracts. The COX-1/SDHA ratio was calculated as an indicator of mitobiogenesis (n = 3 independent experiments). In immunoblots, β-actin was used as a loading control, and the optical density values of the bands representing specific protein immunoreactivity were normalized to β-actin. Data are shown as mean ± SD. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test was applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001). See Supplementary Fig. S6 for uncropped blots.Fig. 2

A key regulatory factor for the mitochondrial genome is the mitochondrial transcription factor A (mtTFA), which is essential for both mtDNA replication and transcription. mtTFA also maintains mtDNA integrity and provides structural stability by compacting the genome into nucleoid structures, reducing its vulnerability to damage from mitochondrial ROS (mtROS) [69,70]. Consistent with the elevated mtDNA levels, we observed that Cu exposure upregulated mtTFA expression (Fig. 2D). The effect was more pronounced after Aβ co-incubation (Fig. 2D). Interestingly, mtTFA immunoblottings from Cu-treated cell extracts revealed smaller bands (Fig. 2D), indicating the presence of short mtTFA isoforms, which are described as less stable but capable of stimulating mitochondrial transcription [71]. The physiological significance of enriching these isoforms with increased Cu levels is unknown and requires further investigation.

In parallel, as a readout of mitochondrial transcription, we determined the protein levels of the mitochondrially encoded cytochrome c oxidase subunit I (COX-1) together with the expression of the nuclear DNA-encoded succinate dehydrogenase complex flavoprotein subunit A (SDHA). While the SDHA levels remained unchanged across all the conditions (Fig. 2E), we observed a Cu-dependent increase in the levels of COX-1. Furthermore, Cu exposure markedly elevated the COX-1/SDHA protein ratio in Aβ-treated cells (Fig. 2E). The high levels of COX-1 and mtTFA in Cu-enriched cells were not modified by GSHee treatment (Fig. 2D and E), suggesting that Cu overload may upregulate mitochondrial transcriptional pathways independently of mtROS signaling.

sec.title: Cu overload promotes an NLRP3 inflammasome-mediated inflammatory response
sec.p:
Next, we analyzed how changes in mitochondrial homeostasis caused by sublethal doses of Cu might influence the inflammatory response of microglia to Aβ. We observed that the activation of SIM-A9 cells by Aβ (5 μM), assessed by the upregulation of AIF-1/IBA1 levels, was stimulated after Cu overload (100 μM) (Fig. 3A). Furthermore, the activated phenotype exhibited by the Cu-treated cells was prevented following GSHee treatment (1 mM) (Fig. 3A). In parallel, as an indicator of NF-κB activation, we evaluated the nuclear presence of the p65 subunit by immunofluorescence microscopy (Fig. 3B). As shown, Cu exposure promoted the nuclear translocation of NF-κB, whereas in untreated cells, p65 NF-κB remained in the cytosol. A similar nuclear translocation was observed in Aβ-treated cells, which was markedly enhanced after Cu overload (Fig. 3B). NF-κB activation in Cu-treated cells was completely blocked by GSHee and MitoQ treatment (Fig. 3B). Our findings point to the involvement of mitochondrial oxidative stress in the induction of the NF-κB pathway elicited by high Cu levels, corroborating previous reports [31].Fig. 3
Cu enrichment induces NLRP3 inflammasome activation leading to a pro-inflammatory microglial profile. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidants GSH ethyl ester (GSHee, 1 mM) and MitoQ (1 μM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. (A) Immunoblot analysis of AIF-1/IBA1 in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). (B) Representative fluorescence micrographs of NF-kb p65 expression and localization. Nuclei were stained with 1 μg/ml Hoechst 33342 (H, blue). Scale bar: 25 μm. The histogram shows mean fluorescence intensities of nuclear NF-κB staining. A total of 50 cells were analyzed per condition; A.U., arbitrary units. (C)Nlrp3 and Il1b mRNA expression levels analyzed by selfie qRT-PCR. Transcript copies were normalized to total genomic DNA and reported as relative levels referred to the expression in control (CTRL) cells (n = 3 independent experiments). (D and E) Representative immunoblots of NLRP3 and IL-1β (37 kDa proform and 17 kDa mature form) in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). (F) Representative confocal images of oligomeric ASC (white arrows) from 3 independent experiments. Cells were transfected with a plasmid encoding an ASC:GFP fusion protein and treated as indicated. Cells were counterstained with CellMask (CM, cytosol/plasma membrane, red). Scale bar: 25 μm. (G) Caspase-1 (CASP-1) activity in cell lysates measured using a pro-bioluminescent substrate (n = 4 independent experiments). A.U., arbitrary units. (H) Levels of IL-1β in cell culture supernatants. In some cases, to assess the presence of IL-1β encapsulated in extracellular vesicles, supernatants were incubated with 1 % Triton X-100 (n = 3 independent experiments). (I) Heat map representation of the cytokine expression profiles. Mouse Cytokine Array was hybridized with cell culture supernatants from CTRL and treated cells and quantified using Mapix software (n = 3 independent experiments). In immunoblots, β-actin was used as a loading control, and the optical density values of the bands representing specific protein immunoreactivity were normalized to β-actin. Data are shown as mean ± SD. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test was applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001). See Supplementary Fig. S6 for uncropped blots.Fig. 3

Different mitochondrial components, including mtROS, ox-mtDNA, and externalized cardiolipin under mitochondrial stress, have been shown to trigger NLRP3 inflammasome induction [39,72,73]. We evaluated whether mtCu enrichment (Fig. 1B) and subsequent oxidative stress (Fig. 1D and E) can promote the NLRP3 inflammasome activation in Aβ-treated cells. We confirmed the transcriptional upregulation of both the Il1b and Nlrp3 genes in SIM-A9 cells exposed to high Cu levels through RT-PCR (Fig. 3C), which led to an increase in the corresponding protein levels, assessed by immunoblotting (Fig. 3D and E). Consistent with the nuclear presence of p65 NF-κB, a slight rise in Nlrp3 and Il1b mRNA levels was also observed in Aβ-treated cells (Fig. 3C), which was significantly enhanced after Cu loading and translated into elevated protein levels (Fig. 3D and E). We determined inflammasome assembly using green fluorescent protein (GFP)- tagged ASC (ASC-GFP). Under normal conditions, the conjugate is evenly distributed in the cytosol; however, it appears as condensed specks when it associates with PRRs such as NLRP3. As shown, Cu enrichment stimulated ASC oligomerization in both control and Aβ-activated cells (Fig. 3F). In parallel, as a direct indicator of inflammasome function, we monitored CASP-1 activity in live cells using the specific Z-WEHD-amino luciferin substrate coupled with a bioluminescence assay. Mirroring the inflammasome assembly, Cu exposure significantly enhanced CASP-1 activity in control and Aβ-treated cells (Fig. 3G). Accordingly, in response to CASP-1 activation, cells incubated with Cu showed increased IL-1β processing (Fig. 3E) and subsequent release of mature IL-1β into the culture media, quantified by ELISA (Fig. 3H). Bioactive cytokines can be secreted within EVs [74,75], a process influenced by cell activation [74]. Due to the inability of cell-free cytokine assays, such as ELISA, to detect cytokines within EVs, we treated the supernatants with 1 % Triton X-100 for 10 min. The resulting detergent-treated media from microglia exposed to Cu showed increased IL-1β levels (Fig. 3H), indicating that Cu enrichment promotes the release of EV-encapsulated IL-1β. Additionally, downregulation of Cu-induced oxidative stress through GSHee or the mitochondria-targeted MitoQ inhibited inflammasome activation (Fig. 3F and G) and significantly decreased IL-1β processing and secretion of both free and EV-associated forms (Fig. 3E and H), in agreement with earlier studies that connect mitochondrial dysfunction to NLRP3 inflammasome engagement [39,76]. To gain a comprehensive understanding of the inflammatory response triggered by Cu, we conducted a cytokine multiplex assay (Fig. 3I). The 24-h conditioned media from Cu-treated cells exhibited elevated levels of proinflammatory cytokines, whereas the levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines remained unchanged (IL-4 and IL-13) or decreased (IL-10). This proinflammatory profile was attenuated by GSHee and MitoQ co-incubation (Fig. 3I). Once again, Cu overload amplified the inflammatory response of microglia in the presence of Aβ (Fig. 3I). These findings indicate that the altered mitochondrial redox balance elicited by high mtCu levels promotes NLRP3 inflammasome activation, which may contribute to perpetuating the pro-inflammatory state of microglia exposed to Aβ.

sec.title: mtDNA oxidation caused by Cu overload triggers NLRP3 inflammasome activation
sec.p:
Previous studies have reported that mtDNA can be released into the cytosol as part of a cell death program and bind to the NLRP3 inflammasome when it becomes oxidized [77]. The requirement of ox-mtDNA for NLRP3 inflammasome activation was further confirmed by Zhong et al. [72], showing that the release of ox-mtDNA is triggered by mtROS and is preceded by the induction of mtDNA de novo synthesis. Given that mitochondrial oxidative stress elicited by Cu overload was accompanied by increased mtDNA copy number (Fig. 2C), we next sought to evaluate whether mtDNA was involved in the Cu-mediated induction of the NLRP3 inflammasome. First, we analyzed the cytosolic presence of mtDNA under Cu-overloaded conditions using SYBR Gold dye, which preferentially labels mitochondrial nucleoids at high dilutions [78]. As expected, confocal micrographs showed SYBR Gold staining localized mainly in mitochondria, and no remarkable increase in cytosolic mtDNA was observed with Cu enrichment (Fig. 4A). The release of mtDNA into the cytosol was also quantified by dPCR, confirming comparable low levels of cytosolic mtDNA regardless of Cu treatment (Fig. 4B). Interestingly, unlike control cells, mitochondria from Cu-exposed cells showed high levels of ox-mtDNA, assessed by immunostaining with anti-8-oxyhydrodioxyguanosine (8-OHdG), a marker of DNA oxidative damage (Fig. 4C). GSHee pre-treatment completely blocked ox-mtDNA generation, thereby corroborating the involvement of oxidative stress. In contrast, the induction of mtDNA oxidation by Cu loading was enhanced in Aβ-treated cells, which displayed an increased mitochondrial size, likely due to swelling and cristae disruption evoked by the cytotoxic peptide itself, as reported previously [79]. Furthermore, the lack of colocalization between some of the 8-OHdG immunostaining spots and mitochondria in Cu-overloaded cells suggested a cytosolic leakage of ox-mtDNA (Fig. 4C, see insets). Additionally, we evaluated the levels of mitochondrial UMP-CMP kinase 2 (CMPK2), the rate-limiting enzyme responsible for providing deoxyribonucleotides for mtDNA synthesis, which was reported to be essential for producing ox-mtDNA fragments [72]. As shown, Cu exposure increased CMPK2 levels, which were even higher in Aβ-activated cells (Fig. 4D). In contrast, treatment with GSHee inhibited Cu-mediated increase of the CMPK2 levels (Fig. 4D). Next, to study the relationship between Cu-induced ox-mtDNA generation and NLRP3 inflammasome activation, we used SIM-A9 cells depleted of mtDNA. The cells were treated with ddC, an analog of the cellular DNA precursor 2′-deoxycytidine-5′-triphosphate (dCTP) that inhibits mitochondrial DNA polymerase (POLG) [80]. As shown, mtDNA copy number declined progressively by up to 75–80 % after 6 days of ddC treatment (Fig. 4E), with almost undetectable presence of cytosolic mtDNA at 3 days of treatment (Fig. 4F). Remarkably, depletion of mtDNA content led to reduced CASP-1 activation, indicating that Cu-induced inflammasome activation was inhibited in both control and Aβ-activated microglia (Fig. 4G). Cells lacking mtDNA also exhibited reduced IL-1β secretion after Cu treatment (Fig. 4H). A complete inhibition of inflammasome induction was achieved when mtDNA downregulation was combined with GSHee treatment (Fig. 4G and H). These findings suggest the participation of cytosolic ox-mtDNA in NLRP3 activation and the enhanced inflammatory response evoked by high Cu levels in Aβ-activated microglia.Fig. 4
The release of oxidized mtDNA (ox-mtDNA) by high Cu levels contributes to NLRP3 inflammasome activation. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidant GSH ethyl ester (GSHee, 1 mM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. (A) Representative confocal photomicrographs showing DNA immunoreactivity (green) in mitochondria labelled with Mitotracker Deep Red (MTK; red). Scale bar: 10 μm. Insets show a 3-fold magnification of the indicated regions. (B) Quantification of mtDNA copies in the cytosolic fraction by multiplex dPCR assay using two different primer pairs (mmt86-ND1 and mmt71-ND4). Values were normalized to total protein levels (n = 5–6 independent experiments). (C) Representative confocal photomicrographs showing 8-hydroxy-2′-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG) immunoreactivity (green) in mitochondria labelled with Mitotracker Deep Red (MTK; red). Scale bar: 10 μm. Insets show a 5-fold magnification of the indicated region. (D) Immunoblot showing the relative levels of cytidine/uridine monophosphate kinase 2 (CMPK2) in cell extracts. β-actin was used as a loading control, and the optical density values of the band corresponding to CMPK2 immunoreactivity were normalized to β-actin (n = 3 independent experiments). (E–H) Cells were treated with the POLG inhibitor mtDNA 2′,3′-dideoxycytidine (ddC,150 μM) for the indicated period of time. (E) Quantification of mtDNA copies after ddC treatment by multiplex dPCR (n = 3 independent experiments). (F) mtDNA copy number in the cytosolic fraction of untreated (NT) and ddC-treated cells for 6 days, with or without Cu exposure. Values were normalized to total protein levels (n = 3–5 independent experiments). (G) Caspase-1 (CASP-1) activity in cell lysates measured using a pro-bioluminescent substrate (n = 4 independent experiments). A.U., arbitrary units. (H) Levels of IL-1β in cell culture supernatants (n = 3 independent experiments). Data are shown as mean ± SD. Unpaired t-test (F) and one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test (B-E, G, H) were applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001). See Supplementary Fig. S6 for uncropped blots.Fig. 4

sec.title: High Cu levels impair microglial Aβ clearance by downregulating ABCA7 levels and phagocytosis
sec.p:
Cu exposure has been reported to influence phagocytosis and reduce Aβ disposal in BV-2 microglial cells [81]. We found a similar effect in SIM-A9 cells. The cells were incubated with fluorescent microbeads for 20 min, and the internalization was analyzed using confocal microscopy. Microglia exhibited basal internalization of fluorescent beads (nonspecific phagocytosis), which was significantly reduced after Cu enrichment (Fig. 5A). A similar inhibitory effect of Cu was observed when cells were activated by Aβ (5 μM) or exposed to bacterial endotoxins, such as LPS (10 μg/ml) and MDP (10 μg/ml), a classical inflammasome inducer (Fig. 5A). In parallel, to evaluate whether Cu exposure affects Aβ clearance, the cells were incubated with fibrilized HiLyte Fluor 488-labelled Aβ for 4 h. Phagocytosis was assessed by confocal microscopy (Fig. 5B). Micrographs revealed a significant downregulation in the amount of fluorescent Aβ phagocytosed when the cells were exposed to Cu. Furthermore, the enhanced Aβ intake displayed by bacterial endotoxin-activated microglia was significantly blunted after Cu enrichment (Fig. 5B). Treatment with GSHee and the mitochondrial antioxidant MitoQ partially mitigated the inhibitory effects of Cu on both nonspecific and Aβ-specific phagocytosis (Fig. 5A and B), suggesting the involvement of mitochondrial oxidative stress.Fig. 5
Exposure to high Cu levels impairs the phagocytic clearance of Aβ mediated by ABCA7. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidants GSH ethyl ester (GSHee, 1 mM) and MitoQ (1 μM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. To reduce intracellular cholesterol levels, Cu-enriched cells were co-incubated with the cholesterol-lowering compound 2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD, 300 μM). (A and B) Representative confocal micrographs from 3 independent experiments showing phagocytosis of yellow-green fluorescent microspheres (A) and HiLyte Fluor 488-labelled Aβ (B). Cells were counterstained with CellMask (CM, cytosol/plasma membrane, red) and Hoechst 33342 (nuclei, blue). To induce phagocytosis cells were stimulated with LPS (10 μg/ml) plus MDP (10 μg/ml) for 16 h. Scale bar: 25 μm. Plots represent phagocytosed beads or Aβ per cell, quantified as the corrected total cell fluorescence (CTCF) of the green channel (n = 10 non-overlapping images). (C) Immunoblots showing the relative levels of ABCA7 and CD36 in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). (D) Representative confocal micrographs from 3 independent experiments showing ABCA7 (green) expression and distribution. Cells were counterstained with CellMask (CM, cytosol/plasma membrane, red) and DAPI (nuclei, blue). Scale bar: 25 μm. (E) Representative confocal images of CTRL and Cu-treated cells immunostained for ABCA7 (red) and incubated with HiLyte Fluor 488-labelled Aβ (green). Scale bar: 25 μm. The Pearson correlation coefficient was used as a measure of colocalization of HiLyte fluor 488 signal (Aβ) with Alexa fluor 555 signal (ABCA7). Three non-overlapping images randomly captured from the upper, middle, and lower areas were analyzed (n = 3 independent experiments). (F) Representative photomicrographs of CTRL and Cu-treated cells labelled with anti-LRP1 (green) and counterstained with CellMask (CM, red) and DAPI (blue). Scale bar: 25 μm. (G) Immunoblot analysis of LRP1 in cytosolic and nuclear fractions (n = 3 independent experiments). In immunoblots, b-actin and LSD1 were used as loading controls for cytosol/cell extracts and nuclear extracts, respectively, and optical density values of the bands representing specific protein immunoreactivity were normalized to b-actin (cytosol/cell extracts) or LSD1 (nuclear extracts). Data are shown as mean ± SD. Unpaired t-test (E, G) and one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test (A–C) were applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001). See Supplementary Fig. S7 for uncropped blots.Fig. 5

Next, we investigated the Cu-dependent mechanism underlying the inefficient removal of Aβ. To this end, we determined the expression levels of the transmembrane glycoprotein receptor CD36 (also known as platelet glycoprotein 4) and the ATP-binding cassette subfamily A member 7 (ABCA7) transporter protein. Both proteins have been reported to mediate microglial Aβ phagocytosis [[82], [83], [84], [85], [86]]. Deficient Aβ phagocytosis has been linked to impaired recycling of CD36 [84]. Similarly, the loss of ABCA7 function has been shown to promote Aβ accumulation and accelerate pathology in AD mouse models [85,86]. We observed that while CD36 remained unchanged, ABCA7 levels decreased following Cu exposure (Fig. 5C). We confirmed the lower ABCA7 content in Cu-exposed cells by immunofluorescence staining (Fig. 5D). The blockage of oxidative stress by GSHee treatment was sufficient to recover ABCA7 levels in Cu-enriched cells (Fig. 5C and D). Micrographs revealed that, in nonreactive microglia, intracellular ABCA7 mainly accumulated at the cell edge (Fig. 5D), likely within endosomal compartments, supporting its role in the vesicular transport of phospholipids and cholesterol [87]. Notably, upon Aβ stimulation, ABCA7 translocates to the plasma membrane, enabling efficient phagocytosis as evidenced by colocalization with fluorescently labelled Aβ peptides (Fig. 5E). Conversely, Cu-enriched cells displaying impaired phagocytic activity showed minimal colocalization of ABCA7 and Aβ (Fig. 5E).

Low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 1 (LRP1) has been described to participate in ABCA7-mediated phagocytosis of apoptotic cells and colocalizes with ABCA7 within the phagocytic cup after macrophage activation [88]. Intriguingly, we found that Cu exposure increased the levels of LRP1; however, unlike in the control cells, the protein appeared restricted to the nucleus (Fig. 5F and G). LRP1 is a heterodimer consisting of a 515 kDa α chain (LRP1α) and an 85 kDa membrane-anchored cytoplasmic β chain (LRP1β). It has been reported that the subunit LRP1β can be processed by γ-secretase and translocate to the nucleus [89,90], where it inhibits transcriptional regulators involved in different inflammatory signaling pathways, such as interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3) and poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1). Further investigation will be needed to assess how LRP1 nuclear translocation and related transcriptional changes affect the microglial inflammatory response after Cu exposure, beyond its impact on phagocytosis.

sec.title: Upregulation of intracellular cholesterol levels caused by Cu overload influences phagocytosis and the immune response of SIM-A9 cells
sec.p:
ABCA7 levels and γ-secretase activity, which is also responsible for amyloidogenic processing [91], are both regulated by cholesterol levels. Active γ-secretase resides in cholesterol-rich membrane microdomains, and membrane cholesterol depletion significantly reduces its enzymatic activity [92]. Likewise, cholesterol-lowering therapies have been shown to raise ABCA7 levels and boost phagocytosis [93,94]. Remarkably, a close relationship has been reported between Cu dysregulation and changes in cholesterol metabolism, although sometimes with contradictory conclusions likely due to tissue- and species-specific differences [95]. We previously showed that sublethal Cu doses stimulate cholesterol synthesis in astrocytes and immature neurons, resulting in cholesterol enrichment in membrane rafts and increased amyloidogenesis [96,97]. In this study, we aimed to analyze the mechanistic link between Cu-mediated cholesterol rise and the induction of a pro-inflammatory microglia profile. As shown, SIM-A9 cells exposed to Cu exhibited a 50–60 % increase in total cholesterol content (Fig. 6A). We also found high mRNA levels of genes related to cholesterol synthesis and transport, such as Srf2, ApoE (apolipoprotein E), and Hmgcr, after Cu overloading regardless of Aβ insult (Fig. 6C). These changes in cholesterol homeostasis were accompanied by increased levels of ER stress response proteins, such as the chaperone BiP and phosphorylated eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2-alpha kinase 3 (EIF2AK3, also known as PERK) (Supplementary Fig. S4), which have been reported to activate the cholesterol biosynthetic pathway [98]. Paralleling total cholesterol rise, the mitochondrial fraction from Cu-overloaded cells showed increased cholesterol levels (Fig. 6A), as confirmed by confocal microscopy (Fig. 6B). We analyzed the intracellular distribution of cholesterol using recombinant perfringolysin O, a cholesterol-binding bacterial toxin fused with glutathione S-transferase (GST-FPO) [51]. In Cu-treated cells, GST-PFO immunostaining partially colocalized with the mitochondrial import receptor subunit TOM20 homolog (TOM20) (Fig. 6B). Furthermore, pre-treatment with GSHee and MitoQ, which significantly reduced the ER stress response (Supplementary Fig. S4), resulted in decreased intracellular cholesterol levels and low colocalization with the mitochondrial marker (Fig. 6B). Additionally, we studied different lipid transfer proteins known to transport cholesterol to the mitochondria. We assessed the expression levels of the endosome-bound transporter stAR-related lipid transfer domain containing 3 (STARD3) [99], as well as the levels of the translocator protein (TSPO) and the steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (STAR), which cooperate to mobilize cholesterol to the mitochondrial inner membrane [100]. As shown, Cu treatment increased the levels of STARD3 and TSPO, while the content of STAR remained unchanged (Fig. 6D). Compared with those in control cells, the levels of STARD3 and TSPO were also elevated in Aβ-activated cells, and Cu exposure further stimulated TSPO expression (Fig. 6D), suggesting that these lipid transfer proteins are responsible for the increase in mitochondrial cholesterol elicited by Cu. To analyze how elevated cholesterol influences the microglial immune response and phagocytosis, Cu-enriched cells were treated with the cholesterol-sequestering compound 2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD, 300 μM). Cyclodextrin treatment normalized cholesterol levels (Fig. 6E) without affecting cell viability (Fig. 6F). The activation of CASP-1 and subsequent release of IL-1β, induced by high levels of Cu, were significantly diminished following HP-β-CD treatment (Fig. 6G and H). Furthermore, HP-β-CD incubation prevented the depletion of ABCA7 in Cu-treated cells (Fig. 6I) and improved the phagocytic capacity of these cells, increasing Aβ intake (Fig. 5A and B). Our findings indicate that upregulation of intracellular cholesterol levels plays a key role in the microglia phenotypic alterations linked to excess Cu.Fig. 6
Cu-induced intracellular cholesterol accumulation alters cholesterol trafficking and impairs the immune response in microglial cells. SIM-A9 cells were exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidant MitoQ (1 μM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. (A) Total cholesterol (CHO) levels in mitochondria-enriched fractions (Mito) and whole-cell homogenates (Cell) (n = 5 independent experiments). (B) Representative confocal photomicrograph of double immunofluorescence for GST-PFO (red) and TOMM20 (green). Scale bar: 50 μm. Line-scan fluorescence intensity profiles of GST-PFO were generated along selected mitochondrial regions. Fluorescence intensity (A.U.) was plotted against the linear distance (μm) to visualise cholesterol distribution within mitochondria. (C) Relative mRNA expression levels of Srebf2, Apoe, and Hmgcr were quantified by selfie qRT-PCR. Transcript copies were normalized to total genomic DNA and reported as relative levels referred to the expression in control (CTRL) cells (n = 3 independent experiments). (D) Immunoblot showing the relative levels of TSPO, STAR, and STARD3 in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). (E–I) To reduce the intracellular cholesterol levels, Cu-enriched cells were co-incubated with the cholesterol-lowering compound 2-hydroxypropyl-β-cyclodextrin (HP-β-CD, 300 μM) (n = 3 independent experiments). (E) Total cholesterol (CHO) content in mitochondria-enriched fractions (Mito) and whole-cell homogenates (Cell). (F) Cell viability assessed by MTT assay. Results are expressed as % relative to control (CTRL) cells. (G) Caspase-1 (CASP-1) activity in cell lysates measured using a pro-bioluminescent substrate. (H) Levels of IL-1β in cell culture supernatants quantified by ELISA. In some cases, to assess the presence of IL-1β encapsulated in extracellular vesicles, supernatants were incubated with 1 % Triton X-100. (I) Immunoblot analysis of ABCA7 in cell extracts (n = 3 independent experiments). In immunoblots, β-actin was used as a loading control, and the optical density values of the bands representing specific protein immunoreactivity were normalized to β-actin. Data are shown as mean ± SD. Unpaired t-test (A) and one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test (C–I) were applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001). See Supplementary Fig. S7 for uncropped blots.Fig. 6

sec.title: SREBF2 overexpression sensitizes APP-PSEN1 neurons to the cytotoxic effects of conditioned media from Cu-treated SIM-A9 cells
sec.p:
Finally, we analyzed the impact of the intensified inflammatory response evoked by Cu overload on neuronal viability. We previously demonstrated that cholesterol enrichment sensitizes neurons to mitochondrial insults, such as Aβ [46]. Additionally, AD mice that overexpress both the mutant APP and PSEN1 genes, together with the cholesterol-related transcription factor SREBF2, exhibit accelerated cognitive deficits and enhanced pathological features, including neuroinflammation [101]. These data prompted us to investigate whether high intracellular cholesterol levels could modify the susceptibility of neuronal cells to Cu-induced reactive microglia (Fig. 7). Embryonic cortical-hippocampal neurons isolated from WT and APP-PSEN1 transgenic mice, with and without SREBF2 overexpression, were exposed to 24-h conditioned media from control and Cu-treated SIM-A9 cells for 16 h. Conditioned media were treated with Chelex before use in neuronal cultures [48], which significantly lowered Cu levels (Supplementary Table S3). After treatment with the ion-exchange resin, the metal-depleted medium was replenished with a specific mixture of metals to restore its growth potential (Supplementary Table S3). We observed a significant reduction in neuronal viability when conditioned media from Cu-treated cells were administered (Fig. 7). The cytotoxic effect was more significant in APP-PSEN1 mutant neurons and was amplified by cholesterol enrichment in APP-PSEN1-SERBF2 cells (Fig. 7). Conversely, viability was maintained, except for in APP-PSEN1-SERBF2 cells, when neuronal cultures were exposed to conditioned media from Cu-overloaded microglia treated with GSHee, which showed a reduced inflammatory profile (Fig. 3H). To confirm the involvement of the NLRP3 inflammasome, SIM-A9 cells were treated with the selective NLRP3 inhibitor MCC950 30 min before exposure to Cu. Treatment with MCC950 significantly reduced Cu-induced CASP-1 activation and IL-1β release in SIM-A9 cells (Supplementary Fig. S5A and Fig. S5B). MCC950-mediated inflammasome inhibition prevented the cytotoxic effects of conditioned media from Cu-treated cells when these media were transferred to WT and all mutant cultures (Fig. 7). Our findings suggest that the inflammatory response of microglia evoked by excess Cu levels can contribute to neuronal death in AD. Furthermore, the fact that changes in intracellular cholesterol levels influence neuronal resilience to the neurotoxic factors released by microglia further supports a key role of cholesterol in controlling neuron-immune cell communications, as we previously reported [40].Fig. 7
Neurotoxic effect of conditioned media from SIM-A9 cells exposed to Cu overload on primary neuronal cultures. Conditioned media (CM) were obtained from SIM-A9 cells exposed to Cu (100 μM) with and without Aβ (5 μM) treatment for 24 h. In some cases, cells were pre-treated with the antioxidant GSH ethyl ester (GSHee, 1 mM) or the NLRP3 inhibitor MCC950 (10 mM) for 30 min before Cu exposure. Primary neuronal cultures from WT and APP-PSEN1 mice with and without SREBF2 overexpression were incubated with conditioned media for 16 h, and cell viability was evaluated by calcein and 7-amino-actinomycin D (7-AAD) double labelling. Representative fluorescence micrographs from three independent experiments are shown, where metabolically active cells are marked by calcein staining (green) and membrane-compromised cells are labelled with 7-AAD (red). Scale bar: 200 μm. The ratio of green (live cells) to red (dead cells) fluorescence was calculated as an indicator of cell viability and expressed as the percentage relative to control (CTRL) values (n = 6 independent experiments). Data are shown as mean ± SD. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's test was applied to calculate statistical significance (∗P < 0.05, ∗∗P < 0.01, ∗∗∗P < 0.001).Fig. 7

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Alzheimer's disease is the most prevalent neurodegenerative disorder worldwide, with age being the leading risk factor for its development. Initially, the amyloid and tau hypotheses sought to explain the disease neuropathology. However, given the limited success of therapies targeting Aβ and tau, alternative hypotheses have emerged. Among them, the amyloid cascade-inflammatory hypothesis [102] suggests that Aβ alone is not sufficient to trigger AD onset, emphasizing instead the role of the immune system and persistent neuroinflammation. This has been further supported by recent genome-wide association studies (GWAS), showing that many of the identified AD risk genes encode factors that regulate immune responses and are enriched in microglia [103,104].

In the present study, we systematically illustrate the impact of Cu overload on sustaining a proinflammatory microglial phenotype in AD. We show that sublethal doses of Cu exert a dual effect on microglia, increasing mtROS and cholesterol levels, which potentiates Aβ-induced cytotoxicity and inflammation and impairs Aβ phagocytosis.

Cu homeostasis is strictly regulated by metallothioneins, which play a crucial role in neutralizing cytosolic Cu [105]. Besides these protective mechanisms, excess intracellular Cu is transported into the mitochondrial matrix for storage [106]. Mitochondria are a primary site for Cu use but are also a key target of harmful Cu overload, especially brain mitochondria, which display lower mtGSH content compared to mitochondria from other tissues [107]. Studies in liver cells and animal models of Wilson disease indicate that mitochondrial structural alterations occur prior to deficits in oxidative phosphorylation and the onset of oxidative damage [108,109]. In these models, elevated mitochondrial ROS appear as a late manifestation, arising only after irreversible mitochondrial damage and cell death. Emerging evidence suggests that Cu cytotoxicity is closely linked to Cu-induced protein conformational changes and proteotoxic stress [110,111], challenging the traditional view of Cu toxicity based on Fenton chemistry and ROS generation. Intriguingly, unlike these previous studies, we observed a dose-dependent increase in mtCu and a simultaneous depletion of mtGSH upon Cu exposure, which led to elevated ROS production and mitochondrial dysfunction without compromising cell viability. Cell-type-specific differences in mtCu handling may explain these seemingly conflicting findings. Within the mitochondrial matrix, most Cu forms non-protein complexes that exceed the requirements for metalloprotein assembly and can accumulate further before functional collapse ensues [106,108,109]. Our findings are consistent with previous work showing that mitochondria from Cu-loaded glioblastoma cells, unlike those from neuronal cells, can sustain markedly elevated Cu levels—up to 40-fold higher than controls— while exhibiting increased ROS production without major structural alterations [107]. The rise in protein carbonyl content, elevated levels of oxidized GSH, and reduced aconitase activity—effects that were all prevented by MitoQ—collectively suggest that oxidative stress is the main driver of mitochondrial damage triggered by Cu overload in microglial cells. In line with this mitochondrial dysfunction, we detected a marked reduction in ATP levels. Notably, MitoQ treatment partially restored ATP content, implying that, in addition to oxidative injury, Cu may exert a direct toxic action on specific mitochondrial protein residues, further contributing to mitochondrial impairment.

Cu-induced mitochondrial oxidative stress favored the NLRP3 inflammasome activation through the release of ox-mtDNA, potentiating the inflammatory response elicited by Aβ. MtCu accumulation has also been reported in activated monocyte-derived macrophages. In these cells, the increase of ionic Cu2+ in mitochondria triggers the oxidation of NADH to NAD+, which contributes to metabolic reprogramming toward a proinflammatory state [112]. The link between mtCu enrichment and neuroinflammation in AD is further substantiated by a recent study showing that lead (Pb) exposure activates microglia and worsens AD pathology by promoting Cu translocation to mitochondria, which leads to enhanced ROS generation and inflammatory cytokine release [113].

We show that mitochondrial oxidative damage linked to Cu overload triggers mitophagy, a protective response to mitochondrial damage. This clearance process is typically upregulated under moderate stress conditions, such as those exerted by sublethal Cu or Aβ doses. Conversely, impaired mitophagy has been reported when Cu is chronically administered or combined with the presence of other neuronal insults, such as α-synuclein, the pathogenic hallmark of Parkinson's disease [114,115]. In line with these findings, mitophagy was significantly blunted in Cu-enriched cells after Aβ treatment. Parallel to the induction of mitophagy, Cu-overloaded cells exhibited an increased mtDNA copy number, together with elevated expression of mtTFA and the mitochondrial-encoded COX-1 protein, indicating the activation of mitobiogenesis signaling pathways. Notably, transcriptional inducers of mtTFA, such as peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma coactivator 1α (PGC-1α) and nuclear respiratory factors 1/2 (NRF-1/-2), are sensitive to redox changes and have been reported to increase following Cu exposure [[116], [117], [118]]. Significantly, we found a higher content of mtDNA in Cu-enriched cells exposed to Aβ, which was accompanied by increased levels of the mitochondrial nucleotide kinase CMPK2. Emerging evidence highlights the critical role of CMPK2 in mitochondria-mediated control of innate immunity [119], which modulates the inflammatory response of monocytes/macrophages and microglia under various pathological conditions, such as ischemic stroke or viral infection [120,121]. Mechanistically, CMPK2-dependent mtDNA synthesis seems to be required for the production of oxidized mtDNA fragments [72]. Ox-mtDNA fragments exit mitochondria via the mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) and voltage-dependent anion channels (VDAC) and can bind NLRP3, unlike unoxidized mtDNA that more readily triggers the activation of other inflammasome sensors, such as AIM2 [72,122,123]. In agreement with these former studies, Cu-overloaded cells showed ox-mtDNA in mitochondria, accompanied by abnormal mitochondrial morphology, most likely swollen mitochondria, when Cu exposure was combined with Aβ. Ox-mtDNA was partially released into the cytosol, as indicated by the lack of colocalization with the mitochondrial marker at some spots, examined by confocal microscopy. Furthermore, the reduction of active CASP-1 and IL-1β maturation after mtDNA depletion confirmed the involvement of the mitochondrial genome in the induction of the NLRP3 inflammasome.

Ox-mtDNA fragments can also activate the cyclic GMP-AMP synthase - stimulating interferon gene (cGAS-STING) signaling pathway [122]. In this regard, mtDNA release and cGAS-STING activation have been reported in chicken hepatocytes after Cu overload under mTFA deficiency [124]. Similarly, in astrocytes, leakage of mtDNA into the cytoplasm caused by Cu exposure has been shown to activate cGAS-STING signaling, which, in cooperation with NLRP3 inflammasome, leads to pyroptotic cell death [125]. Recent studies indicate that STING promotes NLRP3 localization in the ER and facilitates NLRP3 deubiquitination to activate the inflammasome [126]. Thus, further studies are warranted to evaluate the induction of the cGAS-STING pathway and its crosstalk with NLRP3 inflammasome as part of the Cu-mediated inflammatory responses in microglia cells.

Our findings demonstrate that Cu exposure activates the cholesterol biosynthesis pathway and promotes cholesterol accumulation in mitochondria by increasing the expression of lipid transfer proteins, including TSPO and STARD3. In neuronal cells, we have linked these changes in cholesterol metabolism to an ER stress response triggered by Aβ [127]. Our current data also support the induction of ER stress as the mechanism behind cholesterol upregulation by Cu, highlighting mitochondrial oxidative stress as a contributing factor, consistent with the redox regulation of the ER stress response [128].

Results using the cholesterol-lowering compound HP-β-CD indicate that changes in cholesterol synthesis and distribution after Cu loading play a key role in the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome. Our earlier studies revealed that mitochondrial cholesterol enrichment in neuronal cells hampers mitochondrial GSH transport, reducing antioxidant buffering against Aβ-induced mitochondrial ROS [46]. Therefore, it is likely that elevated mitochondrial cholesterol levels in Cu-overloaded microglial cells contribute to ROS-mediated NLRP3 inflammasome activation, partly by compromising the mitochondrial antioxidant defense. Moreover, cholesterol enrichment and subsequent changes in the fluidity of the inner mitochondrial membrane have been shown to affect the efficiency of the respiratory chain, leading to increased mtROS production [129]. Besides raising mitochondrial ROS, cholesterol levels in the ER and the cholesterol-associated SCAP-SREBF2 complex—serving as a scaffold for NLRP3 translocation from the ER to the Golgi—are also reported to induce inflammasome activation [130,131], further emphasizing the mechanistic connection between cholesterol regulation and innate immune signaling. Interestingly, in Cu-enriched cells, some of the IL-1β released upon NLRP3 activation is protected within EVs. Both cholesterol depletion by HP-β-CD and MitoQ treatment not only decreased IL-1β release but also prevented EV encapsulation. EV-encapsulated cytokines are biologically active and more resistant to degradation [74]. The packaging of IL-1β within EVs triggered by Cu overload may facilitate cytokine delivery to target cells while also shielding microglia from autocrine effects.

We have previously demonstrated that intracellular cholesterol enrichment—assessed by incubation with a soluble cholesterol complex—regulates the inflammasome pathway induced by classical stimuli, such as pathogen-associated molecules, differentially in microglia and neuronal cells [40]. In SH-SY5Y neuronal cells, the activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome is linked to mitochondrial oxidative stress and leads to pyroptotic death. In contrast, inflammasome induction under high cholesterol levels in microglial cells promotes a shift toward a neuroprotective phenotype, with upregulated phagocytosis [40]. Intriguingly, unlike Cu-overloaded cells, mtGSH remains unchanged when microglia are externally loaded with cholesterol [40]. Borchard et al. have shown that SH-SY5Y neuronal cells with lower mtGSH levels are more susceptible to Cu damage than glia cells [107]. The study suggests that mtGSH content determines mitochondrial resilience against oxidative damage induced by mitochondria-targeted insults, such as Cu, and may explain the mixed outcomes after inflammasome induction, depending on cell type and cholesterol-loading pathway.

Consistent with a proinflammatory phenotype, microglia cells displayed a significant reduction in the phagocytic capacity following Cu exposure, linked to cholesterol-mediated downregulation of ABCA7 expression. An inverse relationship has been described between ABCA7 levels and cholesterol [87,94]. Intriguingly, ABCA7 levels and phagocytosis normalized in Cu-overloaded cells following treatment with antioxidants, suggesting a potential role for redox regulation, as reported for ABCA1 [132]. Notably, several genetic polymorphisms leading to protein loss-of-function or decreased ABCA7 expression have been identified in samples from AD patients [133]. Furthermore, consistent with the ABCA7 role in Aβ phagocytosis, these AD risk variants are associated with increased Aβ deposition at early disease stages [134]. Interestingly, recent studies have shown that neuronal-specific ABCA7 deficiency in an AD mouse model markedly affects mitochondrial function, exacerbating Aβ pathology and neuronal damage [135]. Whether low ABCA7 levels also affect mitochondrial function in Cu-enriched microglia and how this might contribute to creating a mtROS-mediated inhibitory feedback loop of ABCA7 expression would need further investigation.

Along with decreased ABCA7 levels, the presence of LRP1 at the plasma membrane remained low in Cu-overloaded cells, which may contribute to impairing microglia phagocytosis. Chronic administration of low doses of Cu has been shown to promote proteasomal degradation of LRP1 in endothelial cells, thereby impairing LRP1-dependent Aβ transcytosis [81,136]. Moreover, LRP1 knockdown has been reported to stimulate NF-κB/MAPK-mediated pro-inflammatory signaling pathways in glia cells exposed to Aβ [137]. Unlike these previous studies, we found an abnormal accumulation of LRP1, most likely C-terminal fragments, in the nuclei after Cu loading. Interestingly, nuclear LRP1 forms have been shown to facilitate the nuclear export of inflammatory transcription factors such as the interferon-regulated factor 3 (IRF3), thereby inhibiting the transcriptional activity of inflammatory genes linked to cGAS-STING signaling [90]. Thus, the relocalization of LRP1 in response to Cu overload may play a dual role by regulating both Aβ clearance and Cu-induced inflammatory signaling pathways.

Finally, we showed that conditioned media from Cu-treated microglia cells significantly impacted neuronal viability. Notably, the neurotoxic effect was amplified in APP/PSEN1 neurons overexpressing SREBF2, underscoring the increased vulnerability of cholesterol-enriched neurons to various cellular stressors, as reported in previous studies [40,46]. The neurotoxicity of microglia-conditioned media was completely abolished when NLRP3 activity was selectively inhibited, thus confirming the involvement of the NLRP3 inflammasome. The detrimental effects of sustained proinflammatory cytokine release and their role in neurodegeneration have been extensively documented [138]. More recently, ASC specks have been detected extracellularly and linked to the spread of inflammation [139]. In AD, the release of microglia-derived ASC specks has been implicated in Aβ seeding [140] and proposed as a reliable fluid biomarker of inflammation [141]. It remains to be determined whether Cu-induced microglial proinflammatory profile is accompanied by the release of ASC specks, which, together with impaired phagocytosis, may favor Aβ deposition.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our findings outline the abnormal accumulation of Cu in mitochondria and subsequent mitochondrial oxidative damage as a key factor in regulating microglial behavior in response to immunogenic insults, such as Aβ, supporting the growing evidence that chronic environmental exposure to sub-toxic Cu levels contributes to neuroinflammation and 10.13039/100020014AD progression. From a therapeutic standpoint, the systematic analysis of the underlying mechanisms behind the inflammatory response triggered by Cu overload may open novel therapeutic interventions. In this regard, using different mouse models of acute inflammation, Solier et al. [112] have shown that macrophage activation linked to excess mtCu can be mitigated by administering supformin (LCC-12), a metformin derivative that selectively binds Cu2+ without affecting other divalent metals. Similar approaches aimed at normalizing mtCu levels, combined with other mitochondria-targeted drugs that prevent mitochondrial ROS and ox-mtDNA release, may be a strategy to consider for counteracting metal-driven inflammation and preserving microglial capacity in neurodegenerative diseases.
